doc.title: European Daily: Taking Stock of Euro-Area Inflation Expectations (Vashkinskaya)
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/European Daily Taking Stock of Euro Area Inflation Expectations VashkinskayaEuropean Daily Taking Stock of Euro Area Inf_2025-08-28

processing_metadata.publication: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS
processing_metadata.input_relative_path: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS

passages.text: Following a post- Covid surge, inflation expectations in the Euro area have largely normalised and re- anchored around the ECB's target. That said, some measures of inflation expectations remain elevated, especially at short- term horizons.

We gauge potential upside risks to inflation by extracting a common signal from a wide range of inflation expectations metrics, distinguishing between short and long- term measures. We find that both our composite short- term and long- term inflation expectations factors stand close to \(2\%\) . Also, we find that short- term expectations provide the strongest signals for predicting sequential core inflation over the next few months, while longer- term inflation is better captured by long- term expectations.

Taken together, our analysis suggests that inflation expectations appear well- anchored, with both short- and long- term summary measures close to target. This is consistent with our expectation that inflation will converge back to \(2\%\) .

Inflation expectations in the Euro area increased notably after the pandemic, following a long period of undershooting the target. This increase was more pronounced in short- term expectations, with some of the series going as high as \(6.3\%\) yoy, while long- term expectations generally remained close to target (Exhibit 1, left). Although most indicators normalised after peaking in 2023, some measures of inflation expectations have remained elevated. The latest Survey of Professional Forecasters (SPF) indicates that both short- and long- term expectations have stabilised at higher levels than before Covid (Exhibit 1, right).

Data on inflation expectations vary in several ways: by horizon, economic agent, and data source. While each series serves to capture specific aspects of expectations, extracting a common signal from various measures can provide insight into the overall inflation outlook. In this Daily, we thus construct summary measures for a variety of inflation expectations series to assess their forecasting performance for sequential core inflation and to evaluate potential upside risks to inflation.

Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. For Reg AC certification and other important disclosures, see the Disclosure Appendix, or go to www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.
Exhibit 1: Both Long- and Short-Term Inflation Expectations Are Settling Near Target, Above Pre-Covid Levels
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,Haver Analytics,ECB

Building on our previous work, we group series by horizon: "short- term" if the horizon is one year or less, and "long- term" if the horizon is four years or more. Some series are available since the 1980s at a monthly frequency (European Commission Price Trends Survey), while others are published quarterly (the ECB's SPF) and have limited history, starting in 2020 (the ECB's Consumer Expectations Survey, CES) or 2023 (the ECB's Survey on the Access to Finance of Enterprises, SAFE). We thus aggregate the short- and long- term expectations using a mixed- frequency dynamic factor model (DFM), which estimates a monthly latent factor that loads on all available data points without losing observations to balance the panel.

We first turn to "short- term" series, which include the mean 3 quarter ahead SPF inflation forecast, the median 1 year ahead SAFE and CES inflation expectations, the 12 month ahead European Commission Price Trends Survey, and the average of current and next year Consensus Economics expectations. As the common latent factor extracted via the DFM is not directly interpretable, we map it into the space of the SPF series. We find that our short- term inflation expectations factor currently stands close to \(2\%\) and correlates well with sequential core inflation (Exhibit 2, right).
Exhibit 2: The Short-Term Inflation Expectations Aggregate Now Stands Close to \(2\%\) and Correlates Well With Sequential Core Inflation
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,Haver Analytics,ECB

Similarly, we proceed with the "long- term" inflation expectations series, which include the mean longer- term SPF inflation forecast, the median 5 year ahead SAFE and CES expectations, 6- 10 years ahead Consensus Economics expectations, and a market- based long- term measure of expectations in the form of the 10- year zero- coupon inflation swap rate. Mapping the estimated long- term factor into the SPF longer- term expectations space, we likewise find that long- term expectations look well anchored around \(2\%\) (Exhibit 3).
Exhibit 3: Long-Term Inflation Expectations Have Stayed More Anchored and Are Close to \(2\%\) As Well
Source:Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research,Haver Analytics,ECB

Building on the work of our US colleagues and the Fed, we also construct a broader summary measure that combines all of the above series and map it to the SPF longer- term expectations.2 Testing the in- sample forecasting performance reveals that

short- term expectations are more informative for forecasting sequential core inflation several months ahead, while the long- term inflation outlook is better explained by longer- term expectations, which is quite intuitive (Exhibit 4, left).

The short- term summary measure (DFM ST Factor) outperforms both the best individual short- term series (Consensus Economics short- term expectations) and the short- term SPF series in forecasting near- term inflation variation. The long- term summary measure (DFM LT Factor) performs broadly in line with the long- term SPF. By contrast, the combined summary measure (DFM ST+LT Factor) underperforms the short- term factor for horizons up to 12 months and underperforms the long- term factor at 24- 36 months. Splitting the series by horizon thus improves forecasting performance (Exhibit 4, right).
Exhibit 4: Splitting the Series by Horizon Improves Forecasting Performance
The RMSEs are all normalised by an AR(1) RMSE, with values below 1 reflecting an improvement in forecasting over an AR(1) in months removed.
Source: Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Taken together, our analysis suggests that inflation expectations appear well- anchored, with both short- and long- term summary measures close to target. This is consistent with our expectation that inflation will converge back to \(2\%\) .

We, Sven Jari Stehn, Filippo Taddei, Alexandre Stott, James Moberly, Niklas Garnadt, Katya Vashkinskaya and Giovanni Pierdomenico, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect our personal views, which have not been influenced by considerations of the firm's business or client relationships.

figures.title: Performance in Forecasting MoM Core Inflation
